message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and imaging findings suggest kidney stones, and hematuria is a common presentation in patients with kidney stones. Renal cell carcinoma and proteinuria are not associated with kidney stones. Malignant hypertension is also not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Renal cell carcinoma is not associated with nephrolithiasis or pyramidal medullary calcifications. Hematuria is a common finding in patients with nephrolithiasis and could be expected in this patient. Proteinuria and malignant hypertension are not associated with nephrolithiasis or the described radiographic findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history suggest the presence of nephrolithiasis. It is common to see hematuria in patients with kidney stones. Renal cell carcinoma is unlikely based on the imaging findings. Proteinuria and malignant hypertension are not typically associated with nephrolithiasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and past medical history suggest nephrolithiasis, and the imaging shows the presence of a single radiopaque stone in the ureteropelvic junction and clusters of pyramidal medullary calcifications in both kidneys. Hematuria is a common finding in patients with nephrolithiasis, as the stone can cause irritation and trauma to the ureteral lining. Renal cell carcinoma is unlikely given the imaging findings, and there is no indication of proteinuria or malignant hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In this case, the presence of a single radiopaque stone lodged in the ureteropelvic junction will likely result in hematuria, which is the most likely finding amongst the options listed. The multiple small cysts in medullary pyramids and papillae of both kidneys suggest the patient has medullary sponge kidney, which is a risk factor for developing nephrolithiasis. Renal cell carcinoma, proteinuria, and malignant hypertension are not typically associated with nephrolithiasis or medullary sponge kidney.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a kidney stone can cause injury to the ureteral epithelium, leading to hematuria. The presence of medullary pyramidal calcifications can suggest medullary sponge kidney, which can also present with hematuria. The other options are not necessarily associated with these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a single radiopaque stone found on CT scan suggests nephrolithiasis, which is also confirmed by the patient's medical history. Therefore, hematuria would also be expected in this patient. Options A, C, and D are not associated with nephrolithiasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and CT scan findings suggest nephrolithiasis. Hematuria is commonly seen in patients with nephrolithiasis as the stone irritates and damages the urinary tract lining. The other options are less likely to be seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a radiopaque stone in the ureteropelvic junction and clusters of pyramidal medullary calcifications in both kidneys suggests nephrolithiasis and medullary sponge kidney, respectively. Hematuria is common in both conditions. Renal cell carcinoma, proteinuria, and malignant hypertension are not associated with these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a single radiopaque stone, clusters of pyramidal medullary calcifications, and multiple small cysts in medullary pyramids and papillae of both kidneys suggest the diagnosis of medullary sponge kidney (MSK). MSK is associated with recurrent nephrolithiasis, and hematuria is a common finding. The other options are less associated with the diagnosis of MSK.
